##
malwaretech at 2024-08-30T23:30:54.362Z ##

For a couple of years now I've been trying to assess the likelihood of critical Windows CVEs being mass exploited by reverse engineering the patches for them. A lot of the time, even after figuring out exactly how the vulnerability works, and how to exploit it, the answer is: I simply don't know.

There are so many variables involved, and it usually comes down to whether some security researcher is going to be an asshole by dumping full functional exploit code onto GitHub. For CVE-2024-38063, the bug has all the pieces needed to build a full RCE exploit, but the exploit trigger is contingent on certain network adapter behavior, and possibly also the driver's interrupt timer behavior, neither of which I know much about.

##
malwaretech at 2024-08-30T23:14:23.493Z ##

Wanted to share my thread about vulnerability scoring and overhyping vulnerabilities here too. It primarily stemmed from the discussion about whether CVE-2024-38063 was overhyped or not, but I think it translates well to vulnerability scoring in general.

Many people like to blame vendors or shortcomings in CVSS for overhyping vulnerabilities, but a lot of the time it's just that vulnerability scoring is really really difficult, especially for memory corruption vulnerabilities.

On a technical level, it's hard to know whether a memory corruption is practically and reliably exploitable. Whilst the person who discovered it may not have a stable exploit, someone could later come along and find a different technique that makes the exploit code infinitely more reliable.

Even in cases where a very severe vulnerability is reliably exploitable, widespread exploitation isn't guaranteed. Due to the mechanics of the cybercrime economy, there are very few skilled exploit developers on that side of things. Most of the high caliber vulnerability researchers are either doing cybersecurity work, or selling CNE capabilities to governments.

As a result, a lot of n-day exploitation is going to be low-level targeted attacks by state-sponsored threat actors, rather than indiscriminate mass exploitation by cybercriminals. To many outsiders, it may even appear as if a vulnerability never got picked up and exploited at all. The only people who are going to know any different are the unlucky chosen ones who got targeted.

The five alarm fires, which many of these dire warnings like "this vulnerability is wormable" and "drop everything & patch now" seek to avoid, are near impossible to predict in reality. The WannaCrys, and the BlueKeeps usually have external aggravating factors. In both cases, this was fully function exploit code being released publicly. Most threat actors don't have top-tier exploit development capabilities, but every single one of them can use Google.

The difference between a typical cybersecurity incident and the worst ransomware attack the world has ever seen, can be as simple as one person's decision to publish exploit code. Nobody has a crystal ball to tell if or when that might happen, but by the time it does, it's way too late to start issuing warnings.

So if you're feeling frustrated having to drop everything to patch yet another nothing-burger CVSS 9.0+ vulnerability, just remember that the decision of a single individual can quickly turned that nothing-burger into a threat actor spray & pray free-for-all.

##
briankrebs at 2024-08-30T20:06:05.361Z ##

FYI, an exploit has been released for the zero-click IPv6 vulnerability that Microsoft patched this month in Win 10/11/Server systems. The SANS Internet Storm Center says the released exploit code will cause vulnerable systems to crash, but unreliably.

Chances are decent that some smart people are working on more reliable exploits against this flaw, perhaps even those that actually achieve code execution. Probably best to patch this one soon if you haven't already for some reason.

Further reading (the SANS bit was from their email newsletter):
https://www.theregister.com/2024/08/28/proofofconcept_code_released_for_zeroclick/?is=1ef7934f6635b02395adcab09a0c1b24bf0ea745b648bfe87189de8aadc7300b

https://malwaretech.com/2024/08/exploiting-CVE-2024-38063.html

[Related to CVE-2024-38063 ]

Patch diffing et mise en relation avec la EvilESP CVE-2022–34718 avec PoC

(accessorily) TIL about the Windows binary index https://winbindex.m417z.com/
⬇️
"Breaking down CVE-2024–38063: remote exploitation of the Windows kernel"
👇

https://bi-zone.medium.com/breaking-down-cve-2024-38063-remote-exploitation-of-the-windows-kernel-bdae36f5f61d

#CyberVeille #CVE_2024_38063 #PoC

##
malwaretech@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-30T23:30:54.000Z ##

For a couple of years now I've been trying to assess the likelihood of critical Windows CVEs being mass exploited by reverse engineering the patches for them. A lot of the time, even after figuring out exactly how the vulnerability works, and how to exploit it, the answer is: I simply don't know.

There are so many variables involved, and it usually comes down to whether some security researcher is going to be an asshole by dumping full functional exploit code onto GitHub. For CVE-2024-38063, the bug has all the pieces needed to build a full RCE exploit, but the exploit trigger is contingent on certain network adapter behavior, and possibly also the driver's interrupt timer behavior, neither of which I know much about.

##
malwaretech@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-30T23:14:23.000Z ##

Wanted to share my thread about vulnerability scoring and overhyping vulnerabilities here too. It primarily stemmed from the discussion about whether CVE-2024-38063 was overhyped or not, but I think it translates well to vulnerability scoring in general.

Many people like to blame vendors or shortcomings in CVSS for overhyping vulnerabilities, but a lot of the time it's just that vulnerability scoring is really really difficult, especially for memory corruption vulnerabilities.

On a technical level, it's hard to know whether a memory corruption is practically and reliably exploitable. Whilst the person who discovered it may not have a stable exploit, someone could later come along and find a different technique that makes the exploit code infinitely more reliable.

Even in cases where a very severe vulnerability is reliably exploitable, widespread exploitation isn't guaranteed. Due to the mechanics of the cybercrime economy, there are very few skilled exploit developers on that side of things. Most of the high caliber vulnerability researchers are either doing cybersecurity work, or selling CNE capabilities to governments.

As a result, a lot of n-day exploitation is going to be low-level targeted attacks by state-sponsored threat actors, rather than indiscriminate mass exploitation by cybercriminals. To many outsiders, it may even appear as if a vulnerability never got picked up and exploited at all. The only people who are going to know any different are the unlucky chosen ones who got targeted.

The five alarm fires, which many of these dire warnings like "this vulnerability is wormable" and "drop everything & patch now" seek to avoid, are near impossible to predict in reality. The WannaCrys, and the BlueKeeps usually have external aggravating factors. In both cases, this was fully function exploit code being released publicly. Most threat actors don't have top-tier exploit development capabilities, but every single one of them can use Google.

The difference between a typical cybersecurity incident and the worst ransomware attack the world has ever seen, can be as simple as one person's decision to publish exploit code. Nobody has a crystal ball to tell if or when that might happen, but by the time it does, it's way too late to start issuing warnings.

So if you're feeling frustrated having to drop everything to patch yet another nothing-burger CVSS 9.0+ vulnerability, just remember that the decision of a single individual can quickly turned that nothing-burger into a threat actor spray & pray free-for-all.

##
briankrebs@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-30T20:06:05.000Z ##

FYI, an exploit has been released for the zero-click IPv6 vulnerability that Microsoft patched this month in Win 10/11/Server systems. The SANS Internet Storm Center says the released exploit code will cause vulnerable systems to crash, but unreliably.

Chances are decent that some smart people are working on more reliable exploits against this flaw, perhaps even those that actually achieve code execution. Probably best to patch this one soon if you haven't already for some reason.

Further reading (the SANS bit was from their email newsletter):
https://www.theregister.com/2024/08/28/proofofconcept_code_released_for_zeroclick/?is=1ef7934f6635b02395adcab09a0c1b24bf0ea745b648bfe87189de8aadc7300b

https://malwaretech.com/2024/08/exploiting-CVE-2024-38063.html

##

CVE-2024-43044
(9.1 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 0.05%

updated 2024-08-16T18:33:08

7 posts

Jenkins uses the Remoting library (typically `agent.jar` or `remoting.jar`) for the communication between controller and agents. This library allows agents to load classes and classloader resources from the controller, so that Java objects sent from the controller (build steps, etc.) can be executed on agents. In addition to individual class and resource files, Remoting also allows Jenkins plugin

4 repos

https://github.com/HwMex0/CVE-2024-43044

https://github.com/jenkinsci-cert/SECURITY-3430

https://github.com/convisolabs/CVE-2024-43044-jenkins

https://github.com/v9d0g/CVE-2024-43044-POC

screaminggoat at 2024-09-10T03:13:39.721Z ##

ASEC: Jenkins Servers in Korea With Exposed Vulnerabilities (CVE-2024-23897, CVE-2024-43044)
AhnLab SEcurity intelligence Center (ASEC) highlights the many thousands of internet-exposed Jenkins servers in Korea with identifiable version information, of which 2,824 are vulnerable to CVE-2024-23897 and 3,969 are vulnerable to CVE-2024-43044. They note that both vulnerabilities have publicly available Proofs of Concept (PoC) codes, and that CVE-2024-23897 is reportedly exploited in the wild (linking to CISA's KEV Catalog).

#Jenkins #Cve_2024_23897 #CVE_2024_43044 #vulnerability #CVE #eitw

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-10T03:13:39.000Z ##

ASEC: Jenkins Servers in Korea With Exposed Vulnerabilities (CVE-2024-23897, CVE-2024-43044)
AhnLab SEcurity intelligence Center (ASEC) highlights the many thousands of internet-exposed Jenkins servers in Korea with identifiable version information, of which 2,824 are vulnerable to CVE-2024-23897 and 3,969 are vulnerable to CVE-2024-43044. They note that both vulnerabilities have publicly available Proofs of Concept (PoC) codes, and that CVE-2024-23897 is reportedly exploited in the wild (linking to CISA's KEV Catalog).

#Jenkins #Cve_2024_23897 #CVE_2024_43044 #vulnerability #CVE #eitw

##
screaminggoat at 2024-09-02T14:22:08.324Z ##

When it comes to a vulnerability's exploitability, a proof of concept being disclosed increases those odds. Does every CVE with a PoC get exploited? Definitely not. In this case however, a cybercriminal recently shared a Proof of Concept (PoC) on a dark web forum for CVE-2024-43044, a Jenkins server arbitrary file read vulnerability (See parent toot above for the security advisory). Threat actors talking about exploiting a vulnerability adds a bit more weight to the exploitability odds.

There's a technical analysis and a proof of concept for CVE-2024-43044 if you wanted to learn more.

cc: @todb

#jenkins #CVE_2024_43033 #vulnerability #CVE #proofofconcept #poc

##
patchnow24x7 at 2024-09-02T08:38:59.962Z ##

Update: Exploits for CVE-2024-43044 : Path Transversal vulnerability in Jenkins is available publicly. IF YOU HAVEN'T PATCHED IT YET, PATCH IT NOW!!

Link:
https://github.com/convisolabs/CVE-2024-43044-jenkins?tab=readme-ov-file

https://blog.convisoappsec.com/en/analysis-of-cve-2024-43044/

##

CVE-2024-7262
(7.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 4.70%

updated 2024-08-16T15:32:48

8 posts

Improper path validation in promecefpluginhost.exe in Kingsoft WPS Office version ranging from 12.2.0.13110 to 12.2.0.13489 on Windows allows an attacker to load an arbitrary Windows library. Using the MHTML format allows an attacker to automatically deliver a malicious library on opening the document and a single user click on a crafted hyperlink leads to the execution of the library.

cisakevtracker@mastodon.social at 2024-09-03T15:00:52.000Z ##

CVE ID: CVE-2024-7262
Vendor: Kingsoft
Product: WPS Office
Date Added: 2024-09-03
Vulnerability: Kingsoft WPS Office Path Traversal Vulnerability
Notes: While CISA cannot confirm the effectiveness of patches at this time, it is recommended that mitigations be applied per vendor instructions if available. If these instructions cannot be located or if mitigations are unavailable, discontinue the use of the product.
CVE URL: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2024-7262

##
screaminggoat at 2024-09-03T14:15:01.487Z ##

CISA: CISA Adds Three Known Exploited Vulnerabilities to Catalog
Hot off the press!

  • CVE-2024-7262 (9.3 critical) Kingsoft WPS Office Path Traversal Vulnerability
  • CVE-2021-20124 (7.5 high) Draytek VigorConnect Path Traversal Vulnerability
  • CVE-2021-20123 (7.5 high) Draytek VigorConnect Path Traversal Vulnerability

#CISA #kev #CVE_2024_7262 #CVE_2021_29124 #CVE_2021_20123 #Draytek #kingsoft #vulnerability #CVE #eitw #activeexploitation

##
screaminggoat at 2024-08-28T14:57:44.725Z ##

ESET Research: Analysis of two arbitrary code execution vulnerabilities affecting WPS Office
No surprise that software vendor Kingsoft does not want to disclose in-the-wild zero-day exploitation of CVE-2024-7672 (9.3 critical, published 15 August 2024 and silently patched by Kingsoft sometime March 2024) WPS Office arbitrary code execution via path traversal (!!! cc: @cR0w @reverseics). It is being exploited by a South Korea-aligned Advanced Persistent Threat, called APT-C-60, to target East Asian countries. The final payload is a custom backdoor dubbed SpyGlace. ESET also discovered CVE-2024-7263 (9.3 critical, same info as previous 7262 CVE), which is an alternate method of hijacking the control flow of the same WPS Office plugin component. IOC provided.

See related The Hacker News reporting: APT-C-60 Group Exploit WPS Office Flaw to Deploy SpyGlace Backdoor

#threatintel #IOC #CVE_2024_72762 #CVE_2024_72763 #vulnerability #eitw #activeexploitation #cyberespionage #southkorea #APTC60 #IOC

CVE-2024-7263
(7.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.06%

updated 2024-08-16T15:31:41

4 posts

The patch released in version 12.2.0.16909 to mitigate CVE-2024-7262 was not restrictive enough. Another hyperlink parameter was not properly sanitized which leads to the execution of an arbitrary Windows lib

screaminggoat at 2024-09-04T18:11:48.617Z ##

@happygeek it's a bit late to include this information since you already published it but GrapheneOS Foundation, a Canadian non-profit (privacy-enhanced and security-focused Android distribution) confirmed that CVE-2024-32896 “is the 2nd part of the fix for CVE-2024-29748 vulnerability” which are being actively exploited in the wild by forensic companies. Additionally GrapheneOS notes that “none of this is actually Pixel specific.”

##
screaminggoat at 2024-09-03T18:38:08.437Z ##

Android security advisory: Android Security Bulletin—September 2024
Don't shit your pants like I did when I saw "Note: There are indications that CVE-2024-32896 may be under limited, targeted exploitation." and thought A GODDAMN ZERO-DAY. Well yes, but actually no: CVE-2024-32896 (7.8 high) Android Pixel Privilege Escalation Vulnerability was disclosed back on 11 June 2024. This apparently is a backporting of that patch to the rest of Android.
Don't forget to check out the following updated security bulletins:

  • Pixel Update Bulletin—September 2024
  • Android Automotive OS Update Bulletin—September 2024
  • Wear OS Security Bulletin—September 2024
  • No Pixel Watch (at this time)

No mention of exploitation (of anything new)

#PatchTuesday #Android #vulnerability #CVE

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-04T18:11:48.000Z ##

@happygeek it's a bit late to include this information since you already published it but GrapheneOS Foundation, a Canadian non-profit (privacy-enhanced and security-focused Android distribution) confirmed that CVE-2024-32896 “is the 2nd part of the fix for CVE-2024-29748 vulnerability” which are being actively exploited in the wild by forensic companies. Additionally GrapheneOS notes that “none of this is actually Pixel specific.”

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-03T18:38:08.000Z ##

Android security advisory: Android Security Bulletin—September 2024
Don't shit your pants like I did when I saw "Note: There are indications that CVE-2024-32896 may be under limited, targeted exploitation." and thought A GODDAMN ZERO-DAY. Well yes, but actually no: CVE-2024-32896 (7.8 high) Android Pixel Privilege Escalation Vulnerability was disclosed back on 11 June 2024. This apparently is a backporting of that patch to the rest of Android.
Don't forget to check out the following updated security bulletins:

  • Pixel Update Bulletin—September 2024
  • Android Automotive OS Update Bulletin—September 2024
  • Wear OS Security Bulletin—September 2024
  • No Pixel Watch (at this time)

No mention of exploitation (of anything new)

#PatchTuesday #Android #vulnerability #CVE

##

CVE-2024-29748
(7.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.08%

updated 2024-08-14T18:32:37

2 posts

there is a possible way to bypass due to a logic error in the code. This could lead to local escalation of privilege with no additional execution privileges needed. User interaction is needed for exploitation.

screaminggoat at 2024-09-02T13:32:45.168Z ##

Kaspersky: Head Mare: adventures of a unicorn in Russia and Belarus
Reference: CVE-2023-38831 (7.8 high, disclosed 23 August 2023 by Group-IB as exploited in the wild by cybercriminals, added to CISA's KEV Catalog 24 August 2023, has proof of concept) RARLAB WinRAR Code Execution Vulnerability.

So Head Mare is a hacktivist group that's been active since 2023 and exclusively targets companies in Russia and Belarus. (sus) They conduct phishing campaigns distributing RAR archives that leverage CVE-2023-38831 for initial acess. Some of the discovered tools overlap with previously investigated groups attacking Russian organizations. They deploy LockBit for Windows and Babuk for Linux (ESXi) ransomware. Indicators of compromise provided.

##
screaminggoat at 2024-08-28T13:45:17.719Z ##

Cisco Talos: BlackByte blends tried-and-true tradecraft with newly disclosed vulnerabilities to support ongoing attacks
Reference: CVE-2024-37085 (7.2 high, disclosed 25 June 2024 by Broadcom, added to CISA's KEV Catalog 30 July 2024) VMware ESXi Authentication Bypass Vulnerability.

BlackByte is a ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) group believed to be an offshoot of the Conti ransomware group. They continue leveraging tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs) such as the use of vulnerable drivers (BYOVD) to bypass security protections. They also exploited CVE-2024-37085 shortly after it was disclosed. Cisco highlights a change in the ransomware encryptor that appends “blackbytent_h” file extension to encrypted files (previously unreported), drops four vulnerable driver files now, and uses victim Active Directory credentials to self-propagate. The BlackByte group is also probably more active than its data leak site may imply (only 20-30% of victims have an extortion post). Cisco has recommendations and IOC.

See related The Hacker News reporting: BlackByte Ransomware Exploits VMware ESXi Flaw in Latest Attack Wave

#threatintel #blackbyte #ransomware #raas #conti #CVE_2024_37085 #eitw #IOC #byovd

##

##
screaminggoat at 2024-09-05T14:55:36.784Z ##

Fortinet Threat Actors Exploit GeoServer Vulnerability CVE-2024-36401
References:

  • CVE-2024-36401 (9.8 critical, disclosed 01 July 2024, added to CISA KEV Catalog 15 July 2024) OSGeo GeoServer GeoTools Eval Injection Vulnerability
  • CVE-2017-17215 (8.8 high) Huawei HG532 RCE

Fortinet observed multiple campaigns targeting CVE-2024-36401, including a malicious tool called GOREVERSE that often functions as a reverse proxy server. SideWalk is a Linux backdoor often linked with the hacking group APT41. There's also a Mirai botnet variant called JenX (This malware has a credential list for brute-force attacks and a hard-coded payload related to the Huawei router vulnerability CVE-2017-17215), the Condi botnet, and several CoinMiner cryptomining operations. Indicators of compromise listed.

#threatintel #CVE_2024_36401 #GeoServer #GOREVERSE #IOC #infosec #cybersecurity #eitw #vulnerability #cryptomining

screaminggoat at 2024-09-06T18:10:15.059Z ##

Rapid7: CVE-2024-45195: Apache OFBiz Unauthenticated Remote Code Execution (Fixed)
Rapid7 provides vulnerability details for CVE-2024-45195 (7.5 high, disclosed 04 September 2024 by Apache) Apache OFBiz remote code execution. They claim that CVE-2024-32113, CVE-2024-36104, and CVE-2024-38856 are essentially the same vulnerability with the same root cause. CVE-2024-45195 is a patch bypass for all of those CVEs: “the underlying problem, the ability to fragment the controller-view map state, was not resolved” … “the ability to desynchronize the controller and view map state.” Rapid7 describes the exploitation process. The timeline shows the vulnerability disclosure process and confirmation of patch efficacy.
See related @BleepingComputer reporting: Apache fixes critical OFBiz remote code execution vulnerability

#apache #ofbiz #vulnerability #CVE_2024_45195 #CVE_2024_32113 #CVE_2024_36104 #CVE_2024_38856

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-06T18:10:15.000Z ##

Rapid7: CVE-2024-45195: Apache OFBiz Unauthenticated Remote Code Execution (Fixed)
Rapid7 provides vulnerability details for CVE-2024-45195 (7.5 high, disclosed 04 September 2024 by Apache) Apache OFBiz remote code execution. They claim that CVE-2024-32113, CVE-2024-36104, and CVE-2024-38856 are essentially the same vulnerability with the same root cause. CVE-2024-45195 is a patch bypass for all of those CVEs: “the underlying problem, the ability to fragment the controller-view map state, was not resolved” … “the ability to desynchronize the controller and view map state.” Rapid7 describes the exploitation process. The timeline shows the vulnerability disclosure process and confirmation of patch efficacy.
See related @BleepingComputer reporting: Apache fixes critical OFBiz remote code execution vulnerability

#apache #ofbiz #vulnerability #CVE_2024_45195 #CVE_2024_32113 #CVE_2024_36104 #CVE_2024_38856

##
dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev@dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev at 2024-08-29T16:16:40.000Z ##

I Am The Very Modelfile Of A Modern Workflow General; The Impending ‘Reimagine’ Nightmare;

We return to the semi-regular AI-foucused Drop with a quick look at how to (quickly and easily!) make a custom Ollama model to make a small, useful tool.

Programming note: due to driving #4 to college Friday, there may not be a Drop. But, if the round trip is not too taxing, I’ll likley get one out int he late afternoon.

Type your email…

Subscribe

TL;DR

(This is an AI-generated summary of today’s Drop using Sonnet via Perplexity.)

  • A guide on creating a custom Ollama model using a Modelfile to generate concise names for CVE vulnerabilities, similar to CISA’s KEV catalog entries (https://github.com/ollama/ollama/blob/main/docs/modelfile.md)
  • Discussion of Google’s new Pixel 9 “Reimagine” feature, which allows users to manipulate photos using AI, raising concerns about the potential misuse of such technology (https://www.theverge.com/2024/8/21/24224084/google-pixel-9-reimagine-ai-photos)
  • Introduction to “The Inference,” a new editorial project by Danny Palmer published by Darktrace, exploring the impact of AI on cybersecurity and society (https://darktrace.com/the-inference)

I Am The Very Modelfile Of A Modern Workflow General

[🖼 dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/wp-cont…]Photo by Pixabay on Pexels.com

Longtime readers know I’m #notAFan of the “Open AI tax”. TL;DR for new readers is that I believe it is yugely important to ensure everyone had access to LLM/GPT tooling. These tools/services are not going away anytime soon; and, not knowing how to work with them puts other folks at an needless advantage. Ollama does a great job helping to level the playing field.

Ollama supports adding layers on top of existing models via something called a Modelfile. It’s a plain text file that lets you add in some parameters, prompts, examples, etc. so you don’t have to shunt them along with each new incantation. The format for these is, essentially:

# commentINSTRUCTION arguments

Some key instructions include:

  • FROM: Identifies the base model (mandatory)
  • PARAMETER: Customizes model behavior through various settings
  • TEMPLATE: Defines the prompt template sent to the model
  • SYSTEM: Sets up system messages
  • ADAPTER: Integrates adapters for QLoRA
  • LICENSE: Specifies legal licenses
  • MESSAGE: Adds preset message histories

You can inspect the configuration of models you download and use pretty simply:

$ ollama show phi:latest --modelfile# Modelfile generated by "ollama show"# To build a new Modelfile based on this, replace FROM with:# FROM phi:latestFROM /path/to/.ollama/models/blobs/sha256-04778965089b91318ad61d0995b7e44fad4b9a9f4e049d7be90932bf8812e828TEMPLATE "{{ if .System }}System: {{ .System }}{{ end }}User: {{ .Prompt }}Assistant:"SYSTEM A chat between a curious user and an artificial intelligence assistant. The assistant gives helpful answers to the user's questions.PARAMETER stop User:PARAMETER stop Assistant:PARAMETER stop System:LICENSE """MIT License … """

(They work in a similar fashion to Dockerfiles.)

You can go here for a more in-depth explanation of the instructions and values. I’m just going to briefly show how to make one to solve a fun “problem”.

I talk quite a bit about CISA’s Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog (KEV), and one nice thing the Keepers of KEV do for us is create a short name for any vulnerability they add to the catalog. CVE entries only have a longer-length description associated with their identifier, like CVE-2024-38856’s Apache OFBiz contains an incorrect authorization vulnerability that could allow remote code execution via a Groovy payload in the context of the OFBiz user process by an unauthenticated attacker.. The KEV entry for that uses the concise name of Apache OFBiz Incorrect Authorization Vulnerability, making it much easier to reference (and has way more info than just a bare CVE identifier).

At $WORK, we got it into our noggins to be as kind as the KEV Keepers and associate a concise name with any CVEs we display (and for an upcoming product/API feature). There is no way we were going to lovingly hand-craft those for a few hundred thousand entries. And, I’m loathe to give any AI vendor money. So, we built a custom PHI model to do this for us! And, are sharing it with y’all right here (we’ll working on posting the CVE ids with concise to GitHub when we’re done cleaning them up).

After a few iterations, here’s the Modelfile we ended up with:

FROM phi:latestPARAMETER temperature 0.0PARAMETER stop "\n"PARAMETER num_predict 30PARAMETER top_p 0.95SYSTEM """You are an AI system specializing in generating concise short names for vulnerabilities described by CVEs. Your task is to convert verbose CVE descriptions into clear, descriptive titles that resemble entries in CISA's Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. Stop generating output immediately after providing the short name.PROMPT Given a CVE description, create a short name similar to those used in CISA's KEV catalog. The short name should be concise, descriptive, and highlight the affected product or vulnerability type. Do not provide additional information or explanations. The response should be under 10 words and should end immediately after the short name.Examples:CVE description: A vulnerability in the TCP/IP stack of Cisco IOS XR Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) condition on an affected device.Short name: Cisco IOS XR TCP/IP Stack DoS VulnerabilityCVE description: Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution Vulnerability. This CVE ID is unique from CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26857, CVE-2021-26858, CVE-2021-27065.Short name: Microsoft Exchange Server RCE VulnerabilityNow, create a short name for this CVE:"""

The temperature controls the “creativity” of the output, with 0.0 being fully deterministic. Even with that, we were getting some odd output behavior, so we added a “please stop generating” hint at when it outputs a newline, set the max number of output tokens to 30 (I may change that to 20), and asked it to only make high “next token” probability choices.

Rather than muck with special tokens, I went with a basic prompt-with-few-shot-examples approach.

To make our new model, we just:

$ ollama create cve-shortener -f ./Modelfile

Then just try it out:

$ ollama run cve-shortener 'Topline Opportunity Form (aka XLS Opp form) before 2015-02-15 does not properly restrict access to database-connection strings, which allows attackers to read the cleartext version of sensitive credential and e-mail address information via unspecified vectors.'Topline Opportunity Form (XLS Opp) Database Vulnerability

Like most LLM/GPT output in API contexts, you’ll need to add some guardrails for cleaning up results or retrying the prompt. (Yes, even with all the constraints in the Modelfile, this one still borks output every so often.)

On my aging Apple Silicon box, each call takes ~200-600ms, depending on the inputs and other system GPU load.

If you find yourself repeating prompts, this is a lightweight way to avoid doing so. And, if you have some similar, focused tasks that need doing, getting a hand from our AI overlords can help save quite a bit of time.

The Impending ‘Reimagine’ Nightmare

[🖼 dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/wp-cont…]Photo by cottonbro studio on Pexels.com

Super quick section, since I believe Welch’s examples say everything vs. have me blather much.

Chris Welch, an editor over at The Verge, acquired one of Google’s new Pixel 9 devices and gave the new Reimagine feature a go and posted some results on Threads and The Verge. This, to me, is a pretty terrifying new capability.

We’re already awash in deepfakes, photorealistic child image exploitation, advanced phishing, and shady political campaigns making it almost impossible to tell truth from fiction. The last thing we needed was to commodify this tech so anyone who can afford a certain class of portable glowing rectangles can get in on the gambit.

Let’s hope the majority of uses are benign/silly.

The Inference

[🖼 dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/wp-cont…]

Another quick section, as this content also speaks for itself pretty well.

Danny Palmer is an excellent writer on cybersecurity topics. He has a new editorial project that’s being published by cybersecurity vendor Darktrace (yeah, that’s “a thing” in my line of work).

The Inference explores the impact of AI on the world around us, starting within the security operations center and expanding to business and society writ large. Features on it analyze data, trends, and perspectives from experts inside and outside of Darktrace to educate and inspire readers about the role that AI plays in enabling innovation and how it can be applied safely and securely.

I link to it since the first few pieces:

  • AI and the biggest election year ever – are we ready?
  • The role of IT support engineering in the age of AI
  • In conversation with Professor Mike Woolridge
  • Malware-as-a-Service: what you need to know about this persistent cyber threat

were very well crafted, and I thought more than a few readers would want to get this into their RSS feeds.

(As usual, I get nothing for Dropping a link to this post, save for providing y’all with something I found interesting.)

FIN

Remember, you can follow and interact with the full text of The Daily Drop’s free posts on Mastodon via @dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev@dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev ☮️

https://dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/2024/08/29/drop-523-2024-08-29-happy-thursdai/

##

CVE-2024-37018
(9.1 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 0.00%

updated 2024-08-05T18:32:49

2 posts

The OpenDaylight 0.15.3 controller allows topology poisoning via API requests because an application can manipulate the path that is taken by discovery packets.

arXiv_csCR_bot@mastoxiv.page at 2024-09-02T06:53:07.000Z ##

Manipulating OpenFlow Link Discovery Packet Forwarding for Topology Poisoning

Mingming Chen, Thomas La Porta, Teryl Taylor, Frederico Araujo, Trent Jaeger
https://arxiv.org/abs/2408.16940 https://arxiv.org/pdf/2408.16940 https://arxiv.org/html/2408.16940

arXiv:2408.16940v1 Announce Type: new
Abstract: Software-defined networking (SDN) is a centralized, dynamic, and programmable network management technology that enables flexible traffic control and scalability. SDN facilitates network administration through a centralized view of the underlying physical topology; tampering with this topology view can result in catastrophic damage to network management and security. To underscore this issue, we introduce Marionette, a new topology poisoning technique that manipulates OpenFlow link discovery packet forwarding to alter topology information. Our approach exposes an overlooked yet widespread attack vector, distinguishing itself from traditional link fabrication attacks that tamper, spoof, or relay discovery packets at the data plane. Unlike localized attacks observed in existing methods, our technique introduces a globalized topology poisoning attack that leverages control privileges. Marionette implements a reinforcement learning algorithm to compute a poisoned topology target, and injects flow entries to achieve a long-lived stealthy attack. Our evaluation shows that Marionette successfully attacks five open-source controllers and nine OpenFlow-based discovery protocols. Marionette overcomes the state-of-the-art topology poisoning defenses, showcasing a new class of topology poisoning that initiates on the control plane. This security vulnerability was ethically disclosed to OpenDaylight, and CVE-2024-37018 has been assigned.

##
arXiv_csCR_bot@mastoxiv.page at 2024-09-02T06:53:07.000Z ##

Manipulating OpenFlow Link Discovery Packet Forwarding for Topology Poisoning

Mingming Chen, Thomas La Porta, Teryl Taylor, Frederico Araujo, Trent Jaeger
https://arxiv.org/abs/2408.16940 https://arxiv.org/pdf/2408.16940 https://arxiv.org/html/2408.16940

arXiv:2408.16940v1 Announce Type: new
Abstract: Software-defined networking (SDN) is a centralized, dynamic, and programmable network management technology that enables flexible traffic control and scalability. SDN facilitates network administration through a centralized view of the underlying physical topology; tampering with this topology view can result in catastrophic damage to network management and security. To underscore this issue, we introduce Marionette, a new topology poisoning technique that manipulates OpenFlow link discovery packet forwarding to alter topology information. Our approach exposes an overlooked yet widespread attack vector, distinguishing itself from traditional link fabrication attacks that tamper, spoof, or relay discovery packets at the data plane. Unlike localized attacks observed in existing methods, our technique introduces a globalized topology poisoning attack that leverages control privileges. Marionette implements a reinforcement learning algorithm to compute a poisoned topology target, and injects flow entries to achieve a long-lived stealthy attack. Our evaluation shows that Marionette successfully attacks five open-source controllers and nine OpenFlow-based discovery protocols. Marionette overcomes the state-of-the-art topology poisoning defenses, showcasing a new class of topology poisoning that initiates on the control plane. This security vulnerability was ethically disclosed to OpenDaylight, and CVE-2024-37018 has been assigned.

CVE-2024-37084
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 0.04%

updated 2024-08-02T15:57:05

3 posts

In Spring Cloud Data Flow versions prior to 2.11.4, a malicious user who has access to the Skipper server api can use a crafted upload request to write an arbitrary file to any location on the file system which could lead to compromising the server

1 repos

https://github.com/Kayiyan/CVE-2024-37084-Poc

maodun at 2024-09-04T05:51:22.886Z ##

CVE-2024-37084: Spring Cloud Remote Code Execution https://blog.securelayer7.net/spring-cloud-skipper-vulnerability/

##
screaminggoat at 2024-09-03T14:35:52.088Z ##

SecureLayer7: CVE-2024-37084: Spring Cloud Remote Code Execution
SecureLayer7 has been churning out zero-day vulnerabilities (publicly releasing information about vulnerabilities without a coordinated vulnerability disclosure with the impacted vendor or assigning CVEs) and proofs of concepts for vulnerabilities. According to Spring.io, Spring Cloud Data Flow is a microservices-based Streaming and Batch data processing platform deployed in Cloud Foundry and Kubernetes. CVE-2024-37084 (9.8 CRITICAL) is an arbitrary file write. SecureLayer7 used patch diffing to determine that it’s an insecure deserialization vulnerability that leads to remote code execution, and provides a proof of concept for it.

#vulnerability #CVE_2024_37084 #spring #cve #proofofconcept #poc

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-03T14:35:52.000Z ##

According to Spring.io, Spring Cloud Data Flow is a microservices-based Streaming and Batch data processing platform deployed in Cloud Foundry and Kubernetes. CVE-2024-37084 (9.8 CRITICAL) is an arbitrary file write. CVE-2024-32113
(9.1 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 90.41%

updated 2024-08-01T21:32:46

9 posts

Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal') vulnerability in Apache OFBiz.This issue affects Apache OFBiz: before 18.12.13. Users are recommended to upgrade to version 18.12.13, which fixes the issue.

3 repos

https://github.com/Mr-xn/CVE-2024-32113

https://github.com/YongYe-Security/CVE-2024-32113

https://github.com/RacerZ-fighting/CVE-2024-32113-POC

screaminggoat at 2024-09-10T15:16:22.115Z ##

Cyble: The Re-Emergence of CVE-2024-32113: How CVE-2024-45195 has amplified Exploitation Risks (emailwall)
Let me save you the click: the attacker IOC is 185[.]190[.]24[.]111. I don't get why they added a "give us your personal contact information for more technical details," this is a security worst practice.

Cyble reports exploitation attempts of CVE-2024-32113, and emphasized that the assigning of CVE-2024-45195 (which Rapid7 claims is a patch bypass for multiple CVEs with the same underlying issue which I believe is "permission check for ProgramExport and EntitySQLProcessor") resulted in more exploitation attempts.

References:

  • CVE-2024-32113 (9.1 critical, disclosed 09 May 2024, added to KEV Catalog 07 August 2024) Apache OFBiz Path Traversal Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-45195 (7.5 high, disclosed 04 September 2024 by Apache) Apache OFBiz remote code execution

#CVE_2024_32113 #CVE_2024_45195 #apache #ofbiz #vulnerability #cve

##
screaminggoat at 2024-09-06T18:10:15.059Z ##

Rapid7: CVE-2024-45195: Apache OFBiz Unauthenticated Remote Code Execution (Fixed)
Rapid7 provides vulnerability details for CVE-2024-45195 (7.5 high, disclosed 04 September 2024 by Apache) Apache OFBiz remote code execution. They claim that CVE-2024-32113, CVE-2024-36104, and CVE-2024-38856 are essentially the same vulnerability with the same root cause. CVE-2024-45195 is a patch bypass for all of those CVEs: “the underlying problem, the ability to fragment the controller-view map state, was not resolved” … “the ability to desynchronize the controller and view map state.” Rapid7 describes the exploitation process. The timeline shows the vulnerability disclosure process and confirmation of patch efficacy.
See related @BleepingComputer reporting: Apache fixes critical OFBiz remote code execution vulnerability

#apache #ofbiz #vulnerability #CVE_2024_45195 #CVE_2024_32113 #CVE_2024_36104 #CVE_2024_38856

Let me save you the click: the attacker IOC is 185[.]190[.]24[.]111. I don't get why they added a "give us your personal contact information for more technical details," this is a security worst practice.

Cyble reports exploitation attempts of CVE-2024-32113, and emphasized that the assigning of CVE-2024-45195 (which Rapid7 claims is a patch bypass for multiple CVEs with the same underlying issue which I believe is "permission check for ProgramExport and EntitySQLProcessor") resulted in more exploitation attempts.

  • CVE-2024-32113 (9.1 critical, disclosed 09 May 2024, added to KEV Catalog 07 August 2024) Apache OFBiz Path Traversal Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-45195 (7.5 high, disclosed 04 September 2024 by Apache) Apache OFBiz remote code execution

##

CVE-2024-6387
(8.1 HIGH)

EPSS: 71.47%

updated 2024-07-30T03:31:55

2 posts

A signal handler race condition was found in OpenSSH's server (sshd), where a client does not authenticate within LoginGraceTime seconds (120 by default, 600 in old OpenSSH versions), then sshd's SIGALRM handler is called asynchronously. However, this signal handler calls various functions that are not async-signal-safe, for example, syslog().

faker at 2024-09-09T15:07:16.551Z ##

It's always amazing how terrible some Nessus checks are.
It's like they never even heard of backported security patches.

Oh, your OpenSSH server reports 'OpenSSH_8.9p1 Ubuntu-3ubuntu0.10'? Well, 8.9 is clearly smaller than 9.8 so you MUST be vulnerable to CVE-2024-6387!

And sometimes I get it, the version just appears as outdated. But Ubuntu even includes enough information in the version string to make it possible to detect it automatically as fully patched.

##

screaminggoat at 2024-09-06T18:10:15.059Z ##

Rapid7: CVE-2024-45195: Apache OFBiz Unauthenticated Remote Code Execution (Fixed)
Rapid7 provides vulnerability details for CVE-2024-45195 (7.5 high, disclosed 04 September 2024 by Apache) Apache OFBiz remote code execution. They claim that CVE-2024-32113, CVE-2024-36104, and CVE-2024-38856 are essentially the same vulnerability with the same root cause. CVE-2024-45195 is a patch bypass for all of those CVEs: “the underlying problem, the ability to fragment the controller-view map state, was not resolved” … “the ability to desynchronize the controller and view map state.” Rapid7 describes the exploitation process. The timeline shows the vulnerability disclosure process and confirmation of patch efficacy.
See related @BleepingComputer reporting: Apache fixes critical OFBiz remote code execution vulnerability

#apache #ofbiz #vulnerability #CVE_2024_45195 #CVE_2024_32113 #CVE_2024_36104 #CVE_2024_38856

##

They claim that CVE-2024-32113, CVE-2024-36104, and CVE-2024-38856 are essentially the same vulnerability with the same root cause. CVE-2024-45195 is a patch bypass for all of those CVEs: “the underlying problem, the ability to fragment the controller-view map state, was not resolved” … “the ability to desynchronize the controller and view map state.” Rapid7 describes the exploitation process. The timeline shows the vulnerability disclosure process and confirmation of patch efficacy.
See related @BleepingComputer reporting: Apache fixes critical OFBiz remote code execution vulnerability

Fortinet provides a threat actor spotlight on Underground Ransomware, concentrating on their attack chain. Initial infection is the exploitation of CVE-2023-36884 (7.5 high, disclosed 11 July 2023 by Microsoft, added to CISA's KEV Catalog 17 July 2024) Windows Search Remote Code Execution Vulnerability. The group may also use other common infection vectors such as email and purchasing access from an Initial Access Broker (IAB). Fortinet describes the ransom note, victimology and data leak site. IOC are provided.

screaminggoat at 2024-08-28T18:16:44.206Z ##

Akamai: Beware the Unpatchable: Corona Mirai Botnet Spreads via Zero-Day
Reference: CVE-2024-7029 (CNA: 8.7 high, disclosed 02 August 2024 by CISA) AVTECH IP camera command injection vulnerability. See parent toot above for initial reporting from Security Week.

Akamai finally provides a writeup explaining the situation: a Corona Mirai variant Botnet is leveraging a previously undisclosed zero-day vulnerability now tracked as CVE-2024-7029 to add vulnerable AVTECH IP camera devices to its collection. IOC are provided. They describe the vulnerability (quoted text verbatim, bold emphasis is Akamai's):

The first active campaign we observed began on March 18, 2024, but analysis showed activity for this variant as early as December 2023. The proof of concept (PoC) for CVE-2024-7029 has been publicly available since at least 2019, but it never had a proper CVE assignment until August 2024.

The exploit of this vulnerability allows an attacker to execute remote code on a target system. Here are some bonus CVEs being exploited in the wild for your consideration (to the KEV Catalog):

The botnet also targeted several other vulnerabilities including a Hadoop YARN RCE, CVE-2014-8361, and CVE-2017-17215.

#threatintel #mirai #botnet #vulnerability #zeroday #cve #CVE_2024_7029 #avtech #cisa #rce #poc #corona #hadoop

screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-28T18:16:44.000Z ##

Akamai: Beware the Unpatchable: Corona Mirai Botnet Spreads via Zero-Day
Reference: CVE-2024-7029 (CNA: 8.7 high, disclosed 02 August 2024 by CISA) AVTECH IP camera command injection vulnerability. See parent toot above for initial reporting from Security Week.

Akamai finally provides a writeup explaining the situation: a Corona Mirai variant Botnet is leveraging a previously undisclosed zero-day vulnerability now tracked as CVE-2024-7029 to add vulnerable AVTECH IP camera devices to its collection. IOC are provided. They describe the vulnerability (quoted text verbatim, bold emphasis is Akamai's):

The first active campaign we observed began on March 18, 2024, but analysis showed activity for this variant as early as December 2023. The proof of concept (PoC) for CVE-2024-7029 has been publicly available since at least 2019, but it never had a proper CVE assignment until August 2024.

The exploit of this vulnerability allows an attacker to execute remote code on a target system. Here are some bonus CVEs being exploited in the wild for your consideration (to the KEV Catalog):

The botnet also targeted several other vulnerabilities including a Hadoop YARN RCE, CVE-2014-8361, and CVE-2017-17215.

dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev@dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev at 2024-08-29T16:16:40.000Z ##

I Am The Very Modelfile Of A Modern Workflow General; The Impending ‘Reimagine’ Nightmare;

We return to the semi-regular AI-foucused Drop with a quick look at how to (quickly and easily!) make a custom Ollama model to make a small, useful tool.

Programming note: due to driving #4 to college Friday, there may not be a Drop. But, if the round trip is not too taxing, I’ll likley get one out int he late afternoon.

Type your email…

Subscribe

TL;DR

(This is an AI-generated summary of today’s Drop using Sonnet via Perplexity.)

  • A guide on creating a custom Ollama model using a Modelfile to generate concise names for CVE vulnerabilities, similar to CISA’s KEV catalog entries (https://github.com/ollama/ollama/blob/main/docs/modelfile.md)
  • Discussion of Google’s new Pixel 9 “Reimagine” feature, which allows users to manipulate photos using AI, raising concerns about the potential misuse of such technology (https://www.theverge.com/2024/8/21/24224084/google-pixel-9-reimagine-ai-photos)
  • Introduction to “The Inference,” a new editorial project by Danny Palmer published by Darktrace, exploring the impact of AI on cybersecurity and society (https://darktrace.com/the-inference)

I Am The Very Modelfile Of A Modern Workflow General

[🖼 dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/wp-cont…]Photo by Pixabay on Pexels.com

Longtime readers know I’m #notAFan of the “Open AI tax”. TL;DR for new readers is that I believe it is yugely important to ensure everyone had access to LLM/GPT tooling. These tools/services are not going away anytime soon; and, not knowing how to work with them puts other folks at an needless advantage. Ollama does a great job helping to level the playing field.

Ollama supports adding layers on top of existing models via something called a Modelfile. It’s a plain text file that lets you add in some parameters, prompts, examples, etc. so you don’t have to shunt them along with each new incantation. The format for these is, essentially:

# commentINSTRUCTION arguments

Some key instructions include:

  • FROM: Identifies the base model (mandatory)
  • PARAMETER: Customizes model behavior through various settings
  • TEMPLATE: Defines the prompt template sent to the model
  • SYSTEM: Sets up system messages
  • ADAPTER: Integrates adapters for QLoRA
  • LICENSE: Specifies legal licenses
  • MESSAGE: Adds preset message histories

You can inspect the configuration of models you download and use pretty simply:

$ ollama show phi:latest --modelfile# Modelfile generated by "ollama show"# To build a new Modelfile based on this, replace FROM with:# FROM phi:latestFROM /path/to/.ollama/models/blobs/sha256-04778965089b91318ad61d0995b7e44fad4b9a9f4e049d7be90932bf8812e828TEMPLATE "{{ if .System }}System: {{ .System }}{{ end }}User: {{ .Prompt }}Assistant:"SYSTEM A chat between a curious user and an artificial intelligence assistant. The assistant gives helpful answers to the user's questions.PARAMETER stop User:PARAMETER stop Assistant:PARAMETER stop System:LICENSE """MIT License … """

(They work in a similar fashion to Dockerfiles.)

You can go here for a more in-depth explanation of the instructions and values. I’m just going to briefly show how to make one to solve a fun “problem”.

I talk quite a bit about CISA’s Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog (KEV), and one nice thing the Keepers of KEV do for us is create a short name for any vulnerability they add to the catalog. CVE entries only have a longer-length description associated with their identifier, like CVE-2024-38856’s Apache OFBiz contains an incorrect authorization vulnerability that could allow remote code execution via a Groovy payload in the context of the OFBiz user process by an unauthenticated attacker.. The KEV entry for that uses the concise name of Apache OFBiz Incorrect Authorization Vulnerability, making it much easier to reference (and has way more info than just a bare CVE identifier).

At $WORK, we got it into our noggins to be as kind as the KEV Keepers and associate a concise name with any CVEs we display (and for an upcoming product/API feature). There is no way we were going to lovingly hand-craft those for a few hundred thousand entries. And, I’m loathe to give any AI vendor money. So, we built a custom PHI model to do this for us! And, are sharing it with y’all right here (we’ll working on posting the CVE ids with concise to GitHub when we’re done cleaning them up).

After a few iterations, here’s the Modelfile we ended up with:

FROM phi:latestPARAMETER temperature 0.0PARAMETER stop "\n"PARAMETER num_predict 30PARAMETER top_p 0.95SYSTEM """You are an AI system specializing in generating concise short names for vulnerabilities described by CVEs. Your task is to convert verbose CVE descriptions into clear, descriptive titles that resemble entries in CISA's Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog. Stop generating output immediately after providing the short name.PROMPT Given a CVE description, create a short name similar to those used in CISA's KEV catalog. The short name should be concise, descriptive, and highlight the affected product or vulnerability type. Do not provide additional information or explanations. The response should be under 10 words and should end immediately after the short name.Examples:CVE description: A vulnerability in the TCP/IP stack of Cisco IOS XR Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a denial of service (DoS) condition on an affected device.Short name: Cisco IOS XR TCP/IP Stack DoS VulnerabilityCVE description: Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution Vulnerability. This CVE ID is unique from CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26857, CVE-2021-26858, CVE-2021-27065.Short name: Microsoft Exchange Server RCE VulnerabilityNow, create a short name for this CVE:"""

The temperature controls the “creativity” of the output, with 0.0 being fully deterministic. Even with that, we were getting some odd output behavior, so we added a “please stop generating” hint at when it outputs a newline, set the max number of output tokens to 30 (I may change that to 20), and asked it to only make high “next token” probability choices.

Rather than muck with special tokens, I went with a basic prompt-with-few-shot-examples approach.

To make our new model, we just:

$ ollama create cve-shortener -f ./Modelfile

Then just try it out:

$ ollama run cve-shortener 'Topline Opportunity Form (aka XLS Opp form) before 2015-02-15 does not properly restrict access to database-connection strings, which allows attackers to read the cleartext version of sensitive credential and e-mail address information via unspecified vectors.'Topline Opportunity Form (XLS Opp) Database Vulnerability

Like most LLM/GPT output in API contexts, you’ll need to add some guardrails for cleaning up results or retrying the prompt. (Yes, even with all the constraints in the Modelfile, this one still borks output every so often.)

On my aging Apple Silicon box, each call takes ~200-600ms, depending on the inputs and other system GPU load.

If you find yourself repeating prompts, this is a lightweight way to avoid doing so. And, if you have some similar, focused tasks that need doing, getting a hand from our AI overlords can help save quite a bit of time.

The Impending ‘Reimagine’ Nightmare

[🖼 dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/wp-cont…]Photo by cottonbro studio on Pexels.com

Super quick section, since I believe Welch’s examples say everything vs. have me blather much.

Chris Welch, an editor over at The Verge, acquired one of Google’s new Pixel 9 devices and gave the new Reimagine feature a go and posted some results on Threads and The Verge. This, to me, is a pretty terrifying new capability.

We’re already awash in deepfakes, photorealistic child image exploitation, advanced phishing, and shady political campaigns making it almost impossible to tell truth from fiction. The last thing we needed was to commodify this tech so anyone who can afford a certain class of portable glowing rectangles can get in on the gambit.

Let’s hope the majority of uses are benign/silly.

The Inference

[🖼 dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/wp-cont…]

Another quick section, as this content also speaks for itself pretty well.

Danny Palmer is an excellent writer on cybersecurity topics. He has a new editorial project that’s being published by cybersecurity vendor Darktrace (yeah, that’s “a thing” in my line of work).

The Inference explores the impact of AI on the world around us, starting within the security operations center and expanding to business and society writ large. Features on it analyze data, trends, and perspectives from experts inside and outside of Darktrace to educate and inspire readers about the role that AI plays in enabling innovation and how it can be applied safely and securely.

I link to it since the first few pieces:

  • AI and the biggest election year ever – are we ready?
  • The role of IT support engineering in the age of AI
  • In conversation with Professor Mike Woolridge
  • Malware-as-a-Service: what you need to know about this persistent cyber threat

were very well crafted, and I thought more than a few readers would want to get this into their RSS feeds.

(As usual, I get nothing for Dropping a link to this post, save for providing y’all with something I found interesting.)

FIN

Remember, you can follow and interact with the full text of The Daily Drop’s free posts on Mastodon via @dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev@dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev ☮️

https://dailydrop.hrbrmstr.dev/2024/08/29/drop-523-2024-08-29-happy-thursdai/

#4

screaminggoat at 2024-09-10T15:10:50.860Z ##

At least 10 Fortinet security advisories. Happy #PatchTuesday from Fortinet:

  • FG-IR-22-256 CVE-2024-36511 (CVSSv3.1: 3.7 low) Cookie security policy bypass
  • FG-IR-22-282 CVE-2024-31489 (CVSSv3.1: 6.8 medium) FortiClient - Lack of client-side certificate validation in ZTNA service
  • FG-IR-22-230 CVE-2022-45856 (CVSSv3.1: 4.8 medium) FortiClient(All) - Lack of client-side certificate validation using SAML SSO
  • FG-IR-23-204 CVE-2023-44254 (CVSSv3.1: 5.0 medium) IDOR on download logs feature
  • FG-IR-24-123 CVE-2024-33508 (CVSSv3.1: 7.3 high) Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in a Command in DAS component
  • FG-IR-24-048 CVE-2024-4863 (CVSSv3.1: 7.5 high) Inadequate user validation and no brute force protection on change password requests
  • FG-IR-23-362 CVE-2024-21753 (CVSSv3.1: 5.5 medium) Multiple path traversal in administrative interface
  • FG-IR-24-051 CVE-2024-31490 (CVSSv3.1: 4.3 medium) Sensitive files disclosure in diagnostic logs download
  • FG-IR-24-139 CVE-2024-35282 (CVSSv3.1: 4.2 medium) Unencrypted keychain permanent password
  • FG-IR-24-371 CVE-2024-45323 (CVSSv3.1: 4.3 medium) access to backend information and logs via RestAPI on shared environments

No mention of exploitation. Please note that Fortinet skews their displayed CVSS score (temporal) instead of showing base score, downplaying their severity. Read through these yourself to determine the best course of action

joxean@mastodon.social at 2024-09-06T08:34:35.000Z ##

I have just stumbled upon this post diffing some windows driver:

https://www.crowdfense.com/windows-wi-fi-driver-rce-vulnerability-cve-2024-30078/

Why use #BinDiff and see this [first picture] when you can use #Diaphora and see this [second picture]?

Of course, feel free to use whatever tool you prefer but, what's the point of doing more work? Diaphora finds out that only 2 functions are interesting for patch diffing and shows exactly, in the pseudo-code, what new chunk of code was added and what new function is being called. Diffing decompilation.

CVE-2024-4671
(9.7 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 0.10%

updated 2024-06-10T18:31:01

2 posts

Use after free in Visuals in Google Chrome prior to 124.0.6367.201 allowed a remote attacker who had compromised the renderer process to potentially perform a sandbox escape via a crafted HTML page. (Chromium security severity: High)

avolha at 2024-09-07T11:54:56.820Z ##

Okazało się, że powiązana z rosyjskim rządem grupa APT29, znana też jako Midnight Blizzard czy Cozy Bear, od listopada 2023 r. do lipca 2024 r. korzystała z exploitów na iOS i Androida zaskakująco podobnych do tych, które opracowali komercyjni producenci oprogramowania szpiegującego, tacy jak NSO Group i Intellexa (pierwszy stworzył Pegasusa, drugi Predatora).

Najpierw atakujący włamali się na strony cabinet.gov[.]mn i mfa.gov[.]mn należące do władz Mongolii i posługując się techniką wodopoju (ang. watering hole), dostarczali użytkownikom exploit wykorzystujący lukę CVE-2023-41993 w silniku WebKit na platformie iOS 16.6.1 i starszych. Atak koncentrował się na kradzieży ciasteczek. W kolejnej kampanii grupa zaktualizowała zresztą listę interesujących ją docelowych stron. Według ekspertów niemal identyczny exploit został użyty we wrześniu 2023 r. w oprogramowaniu firmy Intellexa.

Ostatnia opisana w raporcie kampania skupiała się już na użytkownikach Androida. W tym przypadku atakujący posłużyli się exploitami wykorzystującymi podatności CVE-2024-5274 i CVE-2024-4671 w przeglądarce Google Chrome. Badacze ustalili, że exploit na pierwszą z wymienionych luk był podobny do stosowanego przez NSO Group w maju 2024 r., choć koncepcyjnie trochę się od niego różnił. Drugi exploit wykazywał wiele podobieństw do tych, które w przeszłości stworzyła Intellexa.

Badacze nie są pewni, w jaki sposób APT29 uzyskała dostęp do exploitów używanych wcześniej jedynie przez komercyjnych dostawców narzędzi nadzoru. Nie jest wykluczone, że zostały one kupione od brokera luk, który najpierw sprzedał je firmom NSO Group i Intellexa jako 0-dniowe.

Cała analiza: https://blog.google/threat-analysis-group/state-backed-attackers-and-commercial-surveillance-vendors-repeatedly-use-the-same-exploits/

#infosec #cyberbezpieczenstwo #apt29 #nsogroup #intellexa

Okazało się, że powiązana z rosyjskim rządem grupa APT29, znana też jako Midnight Blizzard czy Cozy Bear, od listopada 2023 r. do lipca 2024 r. korzystała z exploitów na iOS i Androida zaskakująco podobnych do tych, które opracowali komercyjni producenci oprogramowania szpiegującego, tacy jak NSO Group i Intellexa (pierwszy stworzył Pegasusa, drugi Predatora).

Najpierw atakujący włamali się na strony cabinet.gov[.]mn i mfa.gov[.]mn należące do władz Mongolii i posługując się techniką wodopoju (ang. watering hole), dostarczali użytkownikom exploit wykorzystujący lukę CVE-2023-41993 w silniku WebKit na platformie iOS 16.6.1 i starszych. W tym przypadku atakujący posłużyli się exploitami wykorzystującymi podatności CVE-2024-5274 i CVE-2024-4671 w przeglądarce Google Chrome. Badacze ustalili, że exploit na pierwszą z wymienionych luk był podobny do stosowanego przez NSO Group w maju 2024 r., choć koncepcyjnie trochę się od niego różnił. Drugi exploit wykazywał wiele podobieństw do tych, które w przeszłości stworzyła Intellexa.

Badacze nie są pewni, w jaki sposób APT29 uzyskała dostęp do exploitów używanych wcześniej jedynie przez komercyjnych dostawców narzędzi nadzoru. Nie jest wykluczone, że zostały one kupione od brokera luk, który najpierw sprzedał je firmom NSO Group i Intellexa jako 0-dniowe.

CVE-2023-48795
(5.9 MEDIUM)

EPSS: 96.53%

updated 2024-05-02T13:18:40

2 posts

### Summary Terrapin is a prefix truncation attack targeting the SSH protocol. More precisely, Terrapin breaks the integrity of SSH's secure channel. By carefully adjusting the sequence numbers during the handshake, an attacker can remove an arbitrary amount of messages sent by the client or server at the beginning of the secure channel without the client or server noticing it. ### Mitigations

Nuclei template

1 repos

#search_error

TomSellers at 2024-08-29T16:27:28.485Z ##

For folks with Synology NAS gear that is a bit older but still new enough to support DSM 7.x:

Synology has released DSM 7.2.2-72803 to fix a bunch of bugs and at least 6 CVEs. One of those CVEs is CVE-2023-48795 which is the Terrapin vuln.

For older gear this will NOT show up in the updates list and will need to be manually downloaded and installed.

Release notes: https://www.synology.com/en-us/releaseNote/DSM

The link above includes a list of models requiring manual install as well as a link to the Download center.

#Security #Patches #Synology

##
TomSellers@infosec.exchange at 2024-08-29T16:27:28.000Z ##

For folks with Synology NAS gear that is a bit older but still new enough to support DSM 7.x:

Synology has released DSM 7.2.2-72803 to fix a bunch of bugs and at least 6 CVEs. One of those CVEs is CVE-2023-48795 which is the Terrapin vuln.

For older gear this will NOT show up in the updates list and will need to be manually downloaded and installed.

Release notes: https://www.synology.com/en-us/releaseNote/DSM

The link above includes a list of models requiring manual install as well as a link to the Download center.

#Security #Patches #Synology

CVE-2024-3094
(10.0 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 14.45%

updated 2024-05-01T19:15:27.340000

4 posts

Malicious code was discovered in the upstream tarballs of xz, starting with version 5.6.0. Through a series of complex obfuscations, the liblzma build process extracts a prebuilt object file from a disguised test file existing in the source code, which is then used to modify specific functions in the liblzma code. This results in a modified liblzma library that can be used by any software linked

Nuclei template

CVE-2024-3400
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 96.30%

updated 2024-04-29T05:02:31

2 posts

A command injection vulnerability in the GlobalProtect feature of Palo Alto Networks PAN-OS software for specific PAN-OS versions and distinct feature configurations may enable an unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary code with root privileges on the firewall. Fixes for PAN-OS 10.2, PAN-OS 11.0, and PAN-OS 11.1 are in development and are expected to be released by April 14, 2024. Cloud NG

Tenable: AA24-241A : Joint Cybersecurity Advisory on Iran-based Cyber Actors Targeting US Organizations
Tenable provides an impressive analysis of CISA's joint cybersecurity advisory about Iranian actors targeting U.S. organizations with ransomware (see parent toots above). They list out the CVEs leveraged, including CVE-2024-3400, CVE-2024-24919, CVE-2019-19781, CVE-2023-3519, CVE-2022-1388, and CVE-2024-21887. (I hate how I recognize every CVE ID based on how often I write about VPN and edge networking device vulnerabilities.) Tenable has graphics of Shodan searches for internet-facing instances, MITRE ATT&CK TTPs, and Tenable plugins.

CVE-2023-41993
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 0.31%

updated 2024-04-26T09:30:33

2 posts

The issue was addressed with improved checks. This issue is fixed in Safari 16.6.1, macOS Ventura 13.6, OS 17.0.1 and iPadOS 17.0.1, iOS 16.7 and iPadOS 16.7. Processing web content may lead to arbitrary code execution. Apple is aware of a report that this issue may have been actively exploited against versions of iOS before iOS 16.7.

4 repos

https://github.com/po6ix/POC-for-CVE-2023-41993

https://github.com/Mangaia/cve-test

https://github.com/J3Ss0u/CVE-2023-41993

https://github.com/hrtowii/cve-2023-41993-test

avolha at 2024-09-07T11:54:56.820Z ##

Okazało się, że powiązana z rosyjskim rządem grupa APT29, znana też jako Midnight Blizzard czy Cozy Bear, od listopada 2023 r. do lipca 2024 r. korzystała z exploitów na iOS i Androida zaskakująco podobnych do tych, które opracowali komercyjni producenci oprogramowania szpiegującego, tacy jak NSO Group i Intellexa (pierwszy stworzył Pegasusa, drugi Predatora).

Najpierw atakujący włamali się na strony cabinet.gov[.]mn i mfa.gov[.]mn należące do władz Mongolii i posługując się techniką wodopoju (ang. watering hole), dostarczali użytkownikom exploit wykorzystujący lukę CVE-2023-41993 w silniku WebKit na platformie iOS 16.6.1 i starszych. Atak koncentrował się na kradzieży ciasteczek. W kolejnej kampanii grupa zaktualizowała zresztą listę interesujących ją docelowych stron. Według ekspertów niemal identyczny exploit został użyty we wrześniu 2023 r. w oprogramowaniu firmy Intellexa.

Ostatnia opisana w raporcie kampania skupiała się już na użytkownikach Androida. W tym przypadku atakujący posłużyli się exploitami wykorzystującymi podatności CVE-2024-5274 i CVE-2024-4671 w przeglądarce Google Chrome. Badacze ustalili, że exploit na pierwszą z wymienionych luk był podobny do stosowanego przez NSO Group w maju 2024 r., choć koncepcyjnie trochę się od niego różnił. Drugi exploit wykazywał wiele podobieństw do tych, które w przeszłości stworzyła Intellexa.

Badacze nie są pewni, w jaki sposób APT29 uzyskała dostęp do exploitów używanych wcześniej jedynie przez komercyjnych dostawców narzędzi nadzoru. Nie jest wykluczone, że zostały one kupione od brokera luk, który najpierw sprzedał je firmom NSO Group i Intellexa jako 0-dniowe.

Cała analiza: https://blog.google/threat-analysis-group/state-backed-attackers-and-commercial-surveillance-vendors-repeatedly-use-the-same-exploits/

#infosec #cyberbezpieczenstwo #apt29 #nsogroup #intellexa

##
avolha@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-07T11:54:56.000Z ##

Okazało się, że powiązana z rosyjskim rządem grupa APT29, znana też jako Midnight Blizzard czy Cozy Bear, od listopada 2023 r. do lipca 2024 r. korzystała z exploitów na iOS i Androida zaskakująco podobnych do tych, które opracowali komercyjni producenci oprogramowania szpiegującego, tacy jak NSO Group i Intellexa (pierwszy stworzył Pegasusa, drugi Predatora).

Najpierw atakujący włamali się na strony cabinet.gov[.]mn i mfa.gov[.]mn należące do władz Mongolii i posługując się techniką wodopoju (ang. watering hole), dostarczali użytkownikom exploit wykorzystujący lukę CVE-2023-41993 w silniku WebKit na platformie iOS 16.6.1 i starszych. Atak koncentrował się na kradzieży ciasteczek. W kolejnej kampanii grupa zaktualizowała zresztą listę interesujących ją docelowych stron. Według ekspertów niemal identyczny exploit został użyty we wrześniu 2023 r. w oprogramowaniu firmy Intellexa.

Ostatnia opisana w raporcie kampania skupiała się już na użytkownikach Androida. W tym przypadku atakujący posłużyli się exploitami wykorzystującymi podatności CVE-2024-5274 i CVE-2024-4671 w przeglądarce Google Chrome. Badacze ustalili, że exploit na pierwszą z wymienionych luk był podobny do stosowanego przez NSO Group w maju 2024 r., choć koncepcyjnie trochę się od niego różnił. Drugi exploit wykazywał wiele podobieństw do tych, które w przeszłości stworzyła Intellexa.

Badacze nie są pewni, w jaki sposób APT29 uzyskała dostęp do exploitów używanych wcześniej jedynie przez komercyjnych dostawców narzędzi nadzoru. Nie jest wykluczone, że zostały one kupione od brokera luk, który najpierw sprzedał je firmom NSO Group i Intellexa jako 0-dniowe.

Cała analiza: https://blog.google/threat-analysis-group/state-backed-attackers-and-commercial-surveillance-vendors-repeatedly-use-the-same-exploits/

CVE-2023-32031
(8.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 9.78%

updated 2024-04-04T04:50:09

2 posts

Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution Vulnerability

1 repos

https://github.com/Avento/CVE-2023-32031

screaminggoat at 2024-09-05T16:29:33.983Z ##

Zero Day Initiative: Exploiting Exchange PowerShell After ProxyNotShell: Part 1 - MultiValuedProperty
This is part 1 of a series of Exchange-related blogs. @chudypb describes CVE-2023-21529 and CVE-2023-32031 (both 8.8 high) Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution vulnerabilities. CVE-2023-21529 is the abuse of the allowed MultiValuedProperty class, while CVE-2023-32031 is the bypass for CVE-2023-21529, abusing the not blocked Command class. He abused both the allow-listed and deny-listed classes to achieve RCE on Exchange. Not only that, he still had two additional full-RCE chains that he was able to deliver after the CVE-2023-32031 patch.

#ZDI #vulnerability #proxynotshell #cve

##
screaminggoat@infosec.exchange at 2024-09-05T16:29:33.000Z ##

Zero Day Initiative: Exploiting Exchange PowerShell After ProxyNotShell: Part 1 - MultiValuedProperty
This is part 1 of a series of Exchange-related blogs. @chudypb describes CVE-2023-21529 and CVE-2023-32031 (both 8.8 high) Microsoft Exchange Server Remote Code Execution vulnerabilities. CVE-2023-21529 is the abuse of the allowed MultiValuedProperty class, while CVE-2023-32031 is the bypass for CVE-2023-21529, abusing the not blocked Command class. He abused both the allow-listed and deny-listed classes to achieve RCE on Exchange. Not only that, he still had two additional full-RCE chains that he was able to deliver after the CVE-2023-32031 patch.

#ZDI #vulnerability #proxynotshell #cve

The issue results from the lack of proper validation of a user-supplied string before u

Summary of Vulnerability A template injection vulnerability on older versions of Confluence Data Center and Server allows an unauthenticated attacker to achieve RCE on an affected instance. Customers using an affected version must take immediate action. Most recent supported versions of Confluence Data Center and Server are not affected by this vulnerability as it was ultimately mitigated during

Nuclei template

https://github.com/cleverg0d/CVE-2023-22527

https://github.com/BBD-YZZ/Confluence-RCE

https://github.com/gobysec/Goby

https://github.com/YongYe-Security/CVE-2023-22527

https://github.com/VNCERT-CC/CVE-2023-22527-confluence

https://github.com/RevoltSecurities/CVE-2023-22527

https://github.com/Avento/CVE-2023-22527_Confluence_RCE

https://github.com/Boogipop/CVE-2023-22527-Godzilla-MEMSHELL

jos1264@social.skynetcloud.site at 2024-09-02T09:55:02.000Z ##

Godzilla Fileless Backdoor Exploits Atlassian Confluence Vulnerability CVE-2023-22527 https://cybersecuritynews.com/godzilla-fileless-backdoor-exploits/ #CyberSecurityNews #cybersecuritynews #CyberSecurity #Vulnerability #cybersecurity #vulnerability

##
VirusBulletin at 2024-09-02T09:28:23.145Z ##

Trend Micro researchers have identified a new attack vector that exploits CVE-2023-22527 through the deployment of an in-memory fileless backdoor known as the Godzilla webshell. https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/24/h/godzilla-fileless-backdoors.html

##
screaminggoat at 2024-08-30T13:05:57.210Z ##

Trend Micro: Silent Intrusions: Godzilla Fileless Backdoors Targeting Atlassian Confluence
Reference: CVE-2023-22527 (CNA: 10.0/NVD: 9.8 critical, disclosed 16 January 2024 by Atlassian, added to CISA's KEV Catalog 24 January 2024) Atlassian Confluence Data Center and Server Template Injection Vulnerability (RCE)

Not even two days later, Trend Micro reports more CVE-2024-22527 exploitation. This time, a loader leads to an in-memory fileless backdoor known as the Godzilla webshell. The original malware author claims that Godzilla avoids detection by using Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) encryption for its network traffic and boasts a very low static detection rate across various security vendor products. Trend Micro describes the infection chain and shares IOC.

#threatintel #godzilla #backdoor #CVE_2023_22527 #Atlassian #Confluence #vulnerability #CVE #eitw #activeexploitation #IOC #infosec #cybersecurity

##
beyondmachines1 at 2024-08-29T15:01:26.166Z ##

Detailed process - how hackers exploit Atlassian CVE-2023-22527
#cybersecurity #infosec #knowledge #awareness
https://beyondmachines.net/event_details/detailed-process-how-hackers-exploit-atlassian-cve-2023-22527-5-m-0-3-o/gD2P6Ple2L

##
VirusBulletin at 2024-08-29T10:44:07.191Z ##

Trend Micro's Abdelrahman Esmail looks into how CVE-2023-22527 is actively being exploited for cryptojacking activities, turning affected environments into cryptomining networks. https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/24/h/cve-2023-22527-cryptomining.html

##
screaminggoat at 2024-08-28T13:47:50.544Z ##

Trend Micro: Cryptojacking via CVE-2023-22527: Dissecting a Full-Scale Cryptomining Ecosystem
Reference: CVE-2023-22527 (CNA: 10.0/NVD: 9.8 critical, disclosed 16 January 2024 by Atlassian, added to CISA's KEV Catalog 24 January 2024) Atlassian Confluence Data Center and Server Template Injection Vulnerability (Remote Code Execution)
Trend Micro details how three main threat actors are exploiting CVE-2023-22527 for cryptomining operations. They also observed a high number of exploitations attempts since from mid-June to the end of July 2024. The resulting activities include deployment of shell scripts and XMRig miners, targeting of SSH endpoints, killing competing cryptomining processes (there's no honor among thieves after all), and maintaining persistence via cron jobs. Trend Micro provides hunting queries, indicators of compromise and mapped MITRE ATT&CK TTPs.

#threatintel #cryptojacking #cryptomining #CVE_2023_22527 #Atlassian #Confluence #eitw #vulnerability #IOC #xmrig #mitreattack

##

CVE-2024-0200
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 6.53%

updated 2024-01-23T19:52:46.093000

2 posts

An unsafe reflection vulnerability was identified in GitHub Enterprise Server that could lead to reflection injection. This vulnerability could lead to the execution of user-controlled methods and remote code execution. To exploit this bug, an actor would need to be logged into an account on the GHES instance with the organization owner role. This vulnerability affected all versions of GitHub Ente

CVE-2024-0507
(8.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.11%

updated 2024-01-23T19:31:32.413000

2 posts

An attacker with access to a Management Console user account with the editor role could escalate privileges through a command injection vulnerability in the Management Console. This vulnerability affected all versions of GitHub Enterprise Server and was fixed in versions 3.11.3, 3.10.5, 3.9.8, and 3.8.13 This vulnerability was reported via the GitHub Bug Bounty program.

Tenable provides an impressive analysis of CISA's joint cybersecurity advisory about Iranian actors targeting U.S. organizations with ransomware (see parent toots above).
